page.title: 13LANGUAGE: Teesdale Dialect 1
page.content: Many of the words used are derivatives from the Anglo-Saxon and Norse languages. Nowadays it is spoken mainly by the farming fraternity but is also seen in place names. {beck }stream {close }small {burn }stream enclosure {broc }badger {common}a tract {brae) }bank,slope of unenclosed {brow) }land {bottom}low part {cut } opening { }of land {crooks}hollow {by }place name {cote} cottage {bower }enclosure {croft }small {booze }stall in a enclosed field { }cow house { carr } a hollow {botany}nickname for place of water remote farm { clough}valley {cleugh}small stream between hills {cop }a mound {comb } bowl {cairn }heap of stones shaped valley {clint }flinty rock {crag } rock
